1:
Can you draw out Leviathan with a fishhook?\q Or tie up his jaws with a cord?
\q
2:
Can you put a rope into his nose,\q or pierce his jaw through with a hook?
\q
3:
Will he make many pleas to you?\q Will he speak soft words to you?


\q
4:
Will he make a covenant with you,\q that you should take him for a servant forever?
\q
5:
Will you play with him as you would with a bird?\q Will you tie him up for your servant girls?
\q
6:
Will the groups of fishermen bargain for him?\q Will they divide him up to trade among the merchants?


\q
7:
Can you fill his hide with harpoons\q or his head with fishing spears?
\q
8:
Put your hand on him just once,\q and you will remember the battle and do it no more.
\q
9:
See, the hope of anyone who does that is a lie;\q will not anyone be thrown down to the ground just by the sight of him?
\m


\q
10:
None is so fierce that he dare stir Leviathan up;\q who, then, is he who can stand before me?
\q
11:
Who has first given anything to me in order that I should repay him?\q Whatever is under the whole sky is mine.
\m
\q
12:
I will not keep silent concerning Leviathan's legs,\q nor about the matter of his strength, nor about his graceful form.


\q
13:
Who can strip off his outer covering?\q Who can penetrate his double armor?
\q
14:
Who can open the doors of his face—\q ringed with his teeth, which are a terror?
\q
15:
his back is made up of rows of shields,\q tight together as with a close seal.
\m


\q
16:
One is so near to another\q that no air can come between them.
\q
17:
They are joined to each other;\q they stick together, so that they cannot be pulled apart.
\q
18:
Light flashes out from his snorting;\q his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning dawn.


\q
19:
Out of his mouth go burning torches,\q sparks of fire leap out.
\q
20:
Out of his nostrils goes smoke\q like a boiling pot on a fire that has been fanned to be very hot.
\q
21:
His breath kindles coals into flame;\q fires go out from his mouth.


\q
22:
In his neck is strength,\q and terror dances in front of him.
\q
23:
The folds of his flesh are joined together;\q they are firm on him; they cannot be moved.
\q
24:
His heart is as hard as a stone—\q indeed, as hard as a lower millstone.


\q
25:
When he raises himself up, even the gods become afraid;\q because of fear, they draw back.
\q
26:
If a sword strikes him, it does nothing—\q and neither does a spear, an arrow, or any other pointed weapon.
\q
27:
He thinks of iron as if it were straw,\q and of bronze as if it were rotten wood.


\q
28:
An arrow cannot make him flee;\q to him sling stones become chaff.
\q
29:
Clubs are regarded as straw;\q he laughs at the whirring flight of a spear.
\q
30:
His lower parts are like sharp pieces of broken pottery;\q he leaves a spreading trail in the mud as if he were a threshing sledge.


\q
31:
He makes the deep to foam up like a pot of boiling water;\q he makes the sea like a pot of ointment.
\q
32:
He makes a shining wake behind him;\q one would think the deep had gray hair.


\q
33:
On earth there is no equal to him,\q who has been made to live without fear.
\q
34: He sees everything that is proud;\q he is king over all the sons of pride."
